title: What happens if I don’t go to school? - Quora

response.answer_text: I will answer assuming you live in the United States of America (USA). This answer may or may not have any validity if you live elsewhere. I will not discuss what can happen if you are below the minimum age to quit school where you live. Do you have a GED or plan on getting one? If so, future problems will be reduced. If you are in the USA, most jobs including the military will require at least a GED or high school diploma. I disagree with the necessity but that does not change the fact. The USA likes to think of itself as a merit based society. That is a lot of manure but it is how it views itself. People are viewed as more competent based on level of education. Competency is viewed in decreasing order: Doctoral degree > Masters degree > Baccalaureate degree > 2 year degree (vocational technical) > high school diploma > GED > no diploma and no GED. This view like the view of being a merit based society is giant pile of manure of the most reeking kind, but it is what exists. If you are really good at something that people want you will probably do okay. I was from that early age of computer programming before most schools taught it. I was according to multiple bosses in the highest of the elite both in quantity and quality. I never had any formal training in programming, I had a natural talent and read/used reference books for commands in the various languages. Many people excel without formal training. Let us assume you have all the skills and talent for your future desired career. By dropping out of school you will face discrimination. You violate the idea of the merit based society and therefore have no merit. You are a cheater and possibly a thief because you can do something others must train, sometimes for years, to be able to do. You will be viewed as someone to take advantage of or viewed undesirable. Let us assume you do not have the skills and talent for your future career, you can look forward to a miserable life of the lowest paying jobs. You will likely not be able to support a family and after a while probably unable to get a life partner as you offer nothing except yourself. Maybe you can become a full time house husband, washing and ironing the clothes, cleaning the house, preparing meals and doing dishes, and raising the children. Outside the home unless lucky to get a decent paying job you will probably be an economic drain (your income will have to exceed total of child care, transportation costs to/from work, additional insurance if you drive to work, higher cost meals compared to fixing something at home, increased tax liability, … or you actually will be costing household revenue to let you work). And these I have stated are the optimist futures, the probable ones include homelessness, prison, begging, … I do not agree with our societies emphasis on formal education. Among the smarter people I have know one may not have finished junior high (pregnant in early teens and forced to quit school by administration - common back then). She read. She read like a book a day. She watched the news. She watched things like Washington Report, Meet the Press, and Face the Nation. Unfortunately in our formal education attitude society she would be considered by many uneducated, politically unaware, and probably illiterate. You will face the same even if you continue your education through private study. I wish it were not so, but those are your prospects, those will be your handicaps.

There are already kids who don’t go to school. They’re called homeschoolers. Some homeschooling families recreate school at home. So that’s not exactly like not going to school. But some families, unschooling families, support their children exploring their interests. It looks nothing like school. Kids who love animals are supported in exploring animals. Kids who love to write, draw, do puzzles, play sports, read, help people, sell things, build things, are all supported. Additionally the parents expose them to more of the world so they can discover new interests. Those children go onto college if they want when they’re ready. The big advantage they have is they know what they love doing and have already been actively exploring it. College for them is a continuation of what they’ve been doing. But if school were just removed? What would happen would totally depend on what families replaced it with. The wealthy could send their kids to private schools. Or, if there were no schools at all, hire tutors. The middle class has an expectation of learning. Without school. many homeschooling communities band together to offer classes, even creating learning centers. They aren’t schools but more like drop in centers where kids can take a class or meet up with others who share an interest. If there never had been schools, society would be highly stratified. Families or segments of society that didn’t value learning, their kids would likely remain stuck without the skills to move beyond what their parents know. A society can function like that if it’s heavily dependent on unskilled labor. For an industrialized society, it means there are too many unskilled adults and not enough jobs for them. If, though, society in general does value learning, everything kids need in order to become functioning members of society is readily available on the internet and in most communities right now. Families can take advantage of it. All they need is to want to and to see how others successfully do it.

Now if you are talking about elementary and secondary education, are you having difficulties with it? Or do you just want to quit? You will be better off if you finish and graduate as employers prefer to see at least a high school education on your job applications. You would be amazed how much that diploma helps as you start out. It won’t matter much later as you get experience under your belt, but if you show up as a drop out, it could affect you a lot as it will affect the kinds of jobs you will be able to get. But if you don’t think you can get the diploma, get a GED as soon as you can. It isn’t as good but it could help you in the next step. Now, if you are talking about post-secondary, college, well, not everyone is suited for it. I taught high school. In Career and Technical Education classes, or what used to be know as Vocational Education. There is a valid reason for having those classes. Not everyone is suited for college. Not everyone is going to college, nor should everyone go. We have far too many jobs that need to be done by people who don’t wish to get a college degree. But there are trade schools where you could learn to be a plumber or an electrician or a welder (those make good money!), or any number of other careers that require two years or less in school. And those classes are not like college. Most of the classes involve hand’s-on learning. Not just sitting in a class learning from books. Think about it. Why limit yourself? I once spoke to a lawyer who said his most intelligent client was one who had worked offshore and been injured, ending that career. When he healed enough to do something else, he went to trade school and learned a new career and went back to work. Never stop learning. Never stop trying. Be the best YOU you can be.

Many great things. I know. I did not send my 4 kids to school, until college. My results, which were superb, are not at all uncommon. I have two Ivy League graduates, a son at the US Naval Academy and a 15 year old still being educated without going to school. My thoughts on keeping your kids out of school: They learn how to think because they are not being told what to think by school systems. They grow to love learning because they are not tested to death from a very young age. They are able to get more sleep, eat a healthier diet, and grow to be more fit because they are not sitting in stuffy classrooms all day long. They are able to participate in many different sports (all club sports are open to them) and because they have more time during the day and the ability to recover properly with true rest they can truly excel. They have fewer friendships but the ones they have are more meaningful and more real and they know it. They are closer to their siblings. They have ample opportunities to travel and see the world because they are not bound to the 9-months-in-school mentality. Their transcripts are far more interesting to competitive universities. They have huge advantages over the boiler-plate transcripts, reflecting lock-step coursework, from their brick and mortar schooled peers. Colleges love to get home educated kids! Because they spend their weeks in mixed-age groups, they grow to become better conversationalists, able to talk to those younger and much older. Many young people who spend their days in same-age groups are only comfortable communicating in a certain way and usually only with their peers. They understand that many of society’s rules are false. No one ever HAS to go to school to become learned. Most of the world does not know this. Home educated kids do. And this sea-changing knowledge is transferred to other areas of life. It works.

Are we talking HS or college? Legally in the US you must attend school. The age at which school remains a requirement differs by state but in most states you must attend until you are 16, in some states it’s 18 though there are exceptions, including passing a proficiency exam, once a minimum age is reached. School attendance is governed by compulsory education laws and the educational requirement can be met through public, private or home school options as long as the option is state accredited. Failure to attend school to the minimum age has punishment under each state’s truancy interventions and typically involves both parents and students though by HS many students fall through the cracks if they drop out. Post the minimum age/HS there is no requirement to attend school. So if you don’t that’s a personal choice. At that point the question becomes what do you intend to do instead? What kind of job will you get to support yourself or do you have the independent wealth not to require a job? For most people a college degree is required as a minimum to pursue work in many fields particularly white collar work. Without a degree, most white collar professions will be closed to you or severe limitations will be placed on your career path within the field. For example you may be able to secure an administrative position but never rise or move into a managerial one. A college degree increases earnings potential and actual lifetime wealth, For trades, like plumber, mason, mechanic, pipe fitter etc., there are trade schools and apprenticeships to train for these roles. Training for and obtaining a job in a trade can be quite lucrative and many trades have severe shortages of qualified tradesmen/women driving wages up higher as demand outstrips supply. Now there are very successful billionaires that never earned their traditional college degree. Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg would be two great examples alongside Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak. These rare individuals founded multi billion dollar companies and dropped out to lead them. Ted Turner was kicked out of Brown, joined his father’s advertising agency and ultimately turned it into a cable TV empire. These examples are not the norm for the vast majority of the population. In the arts again there are examples of very successful individuals who never attended and or never completed college as well. Their talent is their calling card. Examples include Ellen DeGeneres, Russell Simmons, Oprah Winfrey, Tyler Perry, Steven Spielberg (completed his degree after attaining success as a director), Haim Saban, James Cameron, Rachel Ray, and Mark Burnett. So what happens if you don’t go to HS? If you are under the minimum state age required under the compulsory education laws you and your parents are subject to punishment under state truancy, and a lack of at least a HS degree is severely limiting to future earning potential. Without a HS degree, or it’s equivalent, you will be hard pressed to find work outside minimum wage. What happens if you don’t go to college or trade school? Legally nothing. From a earning potential and career standpoint you may find it difficult to find work in many white collar fields and or find your career path is very limited within the field. Unless of course you are the exception that founds a breakthrough company or has rare talent that makes you a star in the arts then a college degree is a non-issue.

You asked, “What happens if I don’t go to school?” The short answer is, “Nothing,” but a longer answer is, “Nothing much.” If we are talking about Public Education (school that others have paid for so that you can get an education at no cost to you) it is possible that you will be called into court and fined and then sent back to school. Or it is possible that you will just sort of melt into the background and meander from part-time low-wage job to part-time low-wage job. Or you could be full of ambitions and be one of those people who do not learn well in the classical school environment. It could be that you really do want to learn and that you will continue to put forth efforts, work hard and accomplish great things. If the latter is the case, you will come to understand that it would have been easier had you gotten some of the things that others paid for you to have at no cost to you. Beyond public high school, education comes at a cost to you in the forms of cash and time. Those who remain in public high school, only have the cost of time -get as much education as you can while you are young and someone else is paying for it. Education is designed for you to have a better quality of life and in almost all cases, it works out that way. Those who put forth no effort and who do not get an education while they are young, rarely have a good quality of life. On the other hand, those who do try and who do get an education normally have a much better quality of life. Work hard now and be a champion for the rest of your life! The short answer is that it really depends so I’ll speak from my experience as if I hadn’t gone back to school. I’d gotten an associate’s degree in communications that I didn’t end up using for work and I really wanted to study science, but hey, I’d graduated and at the time that was plenty of accomplishment for my age. I could always go back later right? My pay bracket didn’t increase much though so I spent a lot of time bouncing between entry-level positions trying to craft the job of my dreams (in the sciences). I did eventually find a job in healthcare with benefits but I wasn’t interested in nursing or the medical field. So there I stayed in my early 20s working 60 hours a week thinking that I was filthy rich. It’s a lot when you start off with a cell phone bill but then the car note comes in, and rent, and gas, and insurance, and the credit cards pile up, and water, and electric, and sewer, and trash, oh and did you want cable and internet too? What about food? See where this is going? Living expenses definitely impacted whether I though I could realistically afford to ever go back to school. The 60 hours I was working would never allow it because I wasn’t actually making much to begin with. I decided then, that if I was going to be making ends meet anyways, I might as well do something I like but when I finally went back to school for my B.S. in Biology, it was so much harder as a working student. I had 2–5 jobs at any given time; part time, overnights, PRN, you name it. I had to piece together a living wage while taking day classes full-time. Not to mention, I felt like I had a lot of ground to cover because I still hadn’t taken the basic bio classes yet like many of my peers. I did graduate and I’m currently working towards my PhD. My life is finally headed in the direction that I want it to go and the pay is much better (some may disagree but I am definitely comfortable) so I don’t regret going back no matter how hard it was. Still, it was a nightmare of a time and I really had to grind the second time around. I could not imagine having had children during this time though there are many who do. Imagine how much more dire such a situation can be with daycare and baby food, and clothes added to all the other expenses. I think back to the time when I first decided to go back. It was hard call to make at the time; all my friends and family lived close by and I had that 60 hour job that wasn’t going anywhere. I cringe now thinking that I could still be working 60 hours a week in my hometown with no lasting passion for my work towards a promotion that might take me 5 years to get. Go to school, graduate with something, whether it’s at a trade school certificate or at a community college degree. Then take some time off and live life. You will likely thank yourself later.

Daniel, If you are talking finishing whatever grade you are in? I can only answer as to what happens in Summit County Ohio where I reside. Ohio law defines truancy as an absence from school without legitimate excuse. The truancy laws apply to students between ages 6 and 18 and recognizes two types of truancy: habitual and chronic. Habitual truancy is the absence from school without a legitimate excuse for 5 or more consecutive days, 7 or more school days in one school month, or 12 or more school days in a school year. Chronic truancy is the absence from school without a legitimate excuse for 7 or more consecutive school days, 10 or more school days in one school month, or 15 or more school days in a school year. Most school attendance policies cite the following excuses for absence as legitimate (supporting documentation may be required): emergencies, funerals, illnesses, medical appointments and religious holidays. Examples of illegitimate excuses include: didn’t feel like going today, had to babysit siblings, missed my ride, overslept, and parents forgot to wake me up. Schools Once a truant student is identified, school districts are required to provide a written notice, warning the student and the parents of the legal consequences and insisting that the student be compelled to attend school immediately. School officials may also request a meeting with student and parents to discuss the reasons behind the youth’s truancy and to find a solution to the problem. If all other measures fail to resolve the truancy problem, school officials are required by law to file a complaint on the youth at Summit County Juvenile Court. School officials may also file failure to send complaints on parents. Parents are legally responsible for enrolling their child in school and making sure their child attends school, unless lawfully excused. Legal Consequences If the Court finds a youth or parent to be in violation of a state truancy law, the following legal consequences may be court ordered:  Bonds, fees and fines (up to $500);  Community service (up to 70 hours);  Counseling;  Electronic monitoring and house arrest; and  Mandatory appearance in Court, mediation or parenting classes. https://co.summitoh.net/juvenilecourt/images/stories/pdfs/Brochures/a%20guide%20to%20understanding%20truancy.pdf

There are many realities that have occurred over the last 30 years in public education. The one thing that is clear is that High School is not the “end” of one’s education. No matter what job that you do after high school, chances are you will need additional training. High School only guarantees that you, hopefully, can read, write, and understand enough to learn more. The opening line of the commencement speech I gave was, “Congratulations, you now have the required skills to get any job that requires you to wear a paper hat.” It is up to you to understand that and determine how you will determine your future. You no longer are accountable to your parents. You are accountable to you and the law. The next thing that I ask is “why do you not want to continue?” There are many reasons for this. I had friends that were so disillusioned by high school teachers that they saw graduation much like obtaining a release from prison. The one thing that you have to understand is that “COLLEGE IS NOT HIGH SCHOOL”. The structure is different and the social norms that you witnessed in high school are not present in college. It also means that you do not have teachers who will seek you out when homework is not turned in on time. While this means that you are the one that is responsible, you are not alone either. Any professor worth their degree, will help you if you ask them. As for the consequences for not going to school, there is not much good news. There are jobs out there for people who have not obtained a college education, but they are getting fewer and fewer. In addition, those jobs are not paid well. Many of my friends who did not go on to college, have had to work longer and at lower positions to get anywhere near a living wage. Despite what many have hoped, the manufacturing jobs that were promised are not coming back. I know that this sounds like a tale of woe. It is a true tale for all too many. The best advice my grandfather gave me was this. “if you want to be a Bum, be the best one there is. Don’t be one because that is all you can do.” There is nothing wrong with taking time away from school once you have graduated. You don’t have to start with a full semester at a college. However, there are some things that you can do to make a better and informed decision. I would go to a guidance counsellor at a community college and discuss with them honestly what you would like to do. They can then advise you as to what kinds of possibilities there are available. In addition, you can go to a community college and take just one course. Most community colleges are open enrollment and don’t require you to be admitted in a traditional manner. Take one course and see what happens. Take advantage of the resources at the college that can help guide your decisions and know that you are making an informed decision that is yours. Education is always an asset even if you don’t get a degree.

Question: What happens if I don’t go to school? First, it depends on what year you’re in and how old you are. If you are under 16, for example, an officer may come to your door eventually and compel you to go to school. There may be penalties for your parents and yourself. Otherwise, really, nothing happens. That’s right: Nothing. But then, the consequences are that nothing happens, too. There will come a time when you will need to find a job, earn a salary, pay for food and shelter, and so on. Your earlier choice will dictate the opportunities you can pursue for employment, and those opportunities are likely to be few in number. You will not be able to aspire to higher positions until you can show some educational achievements, such as a high school diploma (or GED), a trade school certificate, associate degree, bachelor’s degree, master’s degree… Your life path and career path are up to you. What do you want to do? What do you want to be? Your choice to attend school will influence what opportunities are available to you.
